Context:
Program Name: Food and Beverage Management – Restaurant Management
Code: H132
Credential: Ontario College Diploma
Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Method of Study: Full-time
Starting Months: January, May, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,707.00 *
International Tuition: $18,835.00 **
Location: St. James Campus
Experiential Learning: Incorporated in all CHCA programs
Related Programs: Tourism and Hospitality Management (H130), Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management (H133), Culinary Management (H100)
Program Overview: Prepare for a career in restaurant management with a blend of theoretical knowledge and practical experience. The program lasts for two years and includes courses on wine, mixology, entrepreneurship, and strategic restaurant management.

In the first year, students will gain knowledge in various areas including hotels, event planning, tourism, and food and beverages through both practical and theoretical courses. In the second year, students will apply their understanding of theory to exciting learning opportunities and practical experience. One such opportunity is taking over "The Chefs' House", a state-of-the-art facility for hands-on learning.

* Domestic tuition is for Canadian students
** International tuition is for students requiring a study permit
Program Availability: Fall 2024, Winter 2025, Spring 2025. Domestic and international applications are open for the Fall 2024 and Winter 2025 semesters, while international applicants can apply starting April 8, 2024, for the Spring 2025 semester.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Food and Beverage Management – Restaurant Management Program H132 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text describes a Food and Beverage Management program offered by the college with the following key information:

1. Students have the opportunity to manage operations at The Chefs' House restaurant and learning facility, including designing and selling tickets, working with industry partners, performing cost analysis, and creating food and beverage menus.
2. There is an educational virtual simulation where students revitalize a failing restaurant into a profitable enterprise.
3. Students can switch to any of the hospitality and tourism management diploma programs by their second year if their area of interest changes.
4. In their fourth semester, students complete a 14-week industry externship with Canadian or international placements.
5. Graduates receive industry certifications in food safety, responsible alcohol beverage service, and first aid (CPR).
6. Graduates may establish their career paths in various industries such as restaurants, breweries, wineries, resorts, hotels, clubs, and convention centers. Toronto alone has more than 7,500 restaurants and 230 hotels.
7. Qualified graduates of the Food and Beverage – Restaurant Management program may be eligible to earn a diploma and a bachelor’s degree.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Food and Beverage Management – Restaurant Management Program H132 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about a possible educational path for graduates of George Brown College's Food and Beverage – Restaurant Management program. They may be eligible to enter the Honours Bachelor of Business Administration (Hospitality) degree program as an advanced standing student in September or January, or they can start in the spring bridging semester from May to August. The minimum grade point average required to qualify is 2.7.

The text also lists the courses required for the Food and Beverage – Restaurant Management program during Semesters 1, 2, and 3. Here is a summary of those courses:

**Semester 1:**
- HOST1085: Principles of Hospitality and Tourism Management
- HOST1171: Global Accommodation Industry
- HOST1172: Introduction to Wines and Beverages
- HOST1070: Introduction to Catering
- COMM2000: Communicating Across Contexts
- MATH 1250: Introduction to Management Numeracy with Excel Applications
- HOSF 1145: Sanitation (online certificate)
- HOSF 1146: Emergency First Aid and Heartsaver CPR (weekend course)
- Smart Serve (online certificate)

**Semester 2:**
- HOST1174: Remarkable Restaurant Service – An Introduction to the Industry
- HOST1043: Special Events Planning & Delivery
- HOST1173: Hospitality Marketing and Social Media
- HOST1160: Career Preparation
- HOST1175: Global Tourism Geography
- HRM1015: Human Resources Management
- LAW1017: Introduction to Hospitality Law
- ACCT1048: Hospitality Accounting
- GSCI1035: Science of Sustainability

**Semester 3:**
- ACCT2017: Managerial Accounting
- HOST1150: Food & Beverage Cost Control
- HOST1244: Strategic Restaurant Management
- HOST1037: Dining Room Operations
- HOST1011: Mixology
- HOST1199: Entrepreneurship
- GNED: General Education Elective

**Semester 4:**
- HOST 2067: Restaurant Management Simulation (online)
- HOST 2132: Industry Externship
- GNED: General Education Elective

The text also mentions the availability of a Transfer Guide for further information.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Food and Beverage Management – Restaurant Management Program H132 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Program Learning Outcomes:
- Plan, prepare and present quality food and beverage for a variety of hospitality environments.
- Deliver accomplished service of food and beverage for a hospitality enterprise.
- Support an industry and workplace service culture by adopting a positive attitude and professional decorum, accommodating diverse and special needs and contributing as a team member.
- Deliver customer service and solutions that anticipate, meet and/or exceed individual expectations, as well as organizational expectations, standards and objectives.
- Use marketing concepts, market research, social networks, sales and revenue management strategies, relationship management skills and product knowledge to promote and sell hospitality services, products and guest experiences.
- Apply business and revenue models as well as basic accounting, budgeting, financial and administration skills to support the effective management and operation of a variety of organizations delivering hospitality services and products.
- Comply with relevant organization and workplace systems, processes, policies, standards, legal obligations and regulations, and apply risk management principles, to support and maintain efficient, safe, secure, accessible and healthy hospitality operations.
- Use appropriate technologies to enhance the quality and delivery of hospitality services, products and guest experiences and to measure the effectiveness of hospitality operations.
- Keep current with hospitality trends and issues, and interdependent relationships in the broader tourism industry sectors to improve work performance and guide career development.
- Use leadership, teamwork, conflict and relationship management skills and tools, as well as knowledge of organizational behaviour, labour relations, employment standards and human rights to contribute to a positive work environment.
- Respond to issues and dilemmas arising in the delivery of hospitality services, products and guest experiences by using and promoting ethical behaviour and best practices of corporate social responsibility and environmental sustainability.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $4,707.00 
- International Tuition: $18,835.00

Note: The text does not provide any information related to the name or specific program offered by the college.

Context: Program-related inquiries for Food and Beverage Management (H132) can be directed to chcastudentsupport@georgebrown.ca. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. For financial and fees inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit their webpage. The college has various programs including Tourism and Hospitality Management (H130), Hospitality – Hotel Operations Management (H133), and Culinary Management (H100). For more information, contact the international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through the International Contact Us page. Prospective students can join Discovery Days for a first-hand look at facilities and meet with college representatives. To sign up for an Open House Discovery Day, visit their website. For general admissions inquiries, contact admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit their webpage. The college is sensitive to religious observances but may not meet specific dietary laws related to Halal and Kosher foods. Practical labs often use allergens like nuts, dairy, and shellfish. The contact centre can be reached at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
